displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yep and then there’s a starter – a patient starter kit. Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: And then we have to get uh, no you’re good (door closes) Patient: Okay, well God is gonna make sure, Doctor: Yeah. Patient: God is gonna make sure the insurance is taken care of – Doctor: Mm, hmm. PAT - because your wasn’t for sure about the Provenge being taken care of… Patient: …and that was like what a hundred grand. Doctor: That was a hundred grand, yeah. Patient: And so and so the insurance took it right off. Doctor: Yep. Patient: We didn’t have to go to nobody.

Patient: Four. Doctor: Argh! I can’t even trip him off. Family Member: I know. I know. Doctor: Well… you might need chemo. Let me say that again. You might need chemo. Was that whiney enough for you? Family Member: Yeah. Well, at least you have something. You could’ve came in here and said, “Oh, we got nothing for you. Doctor: Oh no, I got tons of stuff for you. The question is when and how and how do you feel about that. Family Member: S___? Patient: I can live with it if I can do the infusion stuff up there. Doctor: Okay. That's a possibility. However, as anything else, we actually have a study. Half the group gets regular chemo, which is IV. The other group gets a pill chemo which is oral. I can't tell you which one you are. And of course, we need you to commit so that if you say there's no freakin way I'm gonna get chemo down here then don't do the trial, but it's a fifty-fifty Family Member: You don't want to come down here xxx do you? Patient: How often do I have to be here? Doctor: Well, chemo is once every three weeks. So if you're good, don't quote me because I botched up a thousand things today in terms of the schedule, which is why I keep my mouth shut half the time. But standard chemo is once every three weeks. Family Member: Oh that’s not too bad.

Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: What I would like to do, is uh I would like to leave you with this information. Please don’t read it now because I want you to take your time with it. Um it’s it’s pretty intense reading but if if you take it slowly, and then maybe you have people in your family with you, going over it with you. Um and then in in about a week um we will call you back up. I will have my research nurse reach out to you by telephone. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And uh see what you think. By then we will have the information from the PSA. And if the PSA is rising again, it it would be my recommendation that at the very least we start the Xtandi. And then addition to that, possibly to consider the clinical trial. But at the very least, I do think Xtandi is going to be a part of your treatment. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And if the PSA has somehow stabilized or dropped on its own, which I don’t anticipate in this case- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But if it has dropped on its own, then I will rewrite your prescription and reauthorize your prescription for the Abiraterone. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But, having said all that, I do anticipate that we’re going to be switching gears. Patient: Okay. Sound good to me. Doctor: Are there any other questions you have for me about the clinical trial or about the Xtandi itself?

Patient: Right. Doctor: Because you have to be positive to go onto that study. The other two studies, it doesn’t matter about what your AR-V7. AR-V7 gives us a sense of what’s the likelihood that Enzalutamide’s gonna work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: What’s the likelihood that Abiraterone’s gonna work. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um. In this case, we’re trying to just sort out men who, um, have an AR-V7 positive as a bad thing. Uh. So, that says that we’re willing to go with immune therapy which hasn’t been proven at a high risk/high gain, uh, thing in that kind of individual. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh. (pause) Patient: Right. Doctor: That it’s clear that this isn’t helping you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, we could say, “No, let’s move on.” I can give you the, uh, consent forms. But, if you already know, that I don’t want to do chemotherapy, I know I’m not going to come in here. The consent form does explain chemotherapy. So, that’s something that you’d be entertaining as a next step, whether it be here or locally.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: I could eat nothing for about, about at least about two days. Doctor: Okay so let me send me over to chemo. Okay? We’ll do the chemo today, but meanwhile I’m going to call our radiologist and see if they can tell me something about the CAT scan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Then I’ll come over there and talk to you about it. Patient: Let me ask you something, let me ask you something Dr. B____. What is what is better, CAT scan or ah MRI? Doctor: It depends on what part of the body we’re looking at. But a CAT scan is pretty good, it’s a pretty good test. If we don’t find something or need to look at it more. Patient: You said it’s not showing on the… Doctor: Well not when we looked quickly, but uh you know we need a radiologists when – that’s why we have that specialty who reads CAT scans. Okay and I’m not one. (laughs) Patient: Yeah, I get it. Doctor: Okay, So as I get things… Patient: I’m gonna wait here until you get back. Cause, definitely how I’m tired and I’m gonna lay down man. Doctor: Yeah, okay. So as we get things sorted out I will come over and talk to you. Patient: Do I have to get any more shots today?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yet? Patient: I just got it just now. Doctor: You did get it okay good. Patient: A couple days ago. Doctor: Yeah because the flu has been bad this year so. Healthcare Professional 1: So he’ll be due for the Lupron his next visit correct? Doctor: Yep Healthcare Professional 1: Okay. Doctor: Well I mean you might as well get it authorized. Healthcare Professional 1: Right. Doctor: If he’s one day here or there (mumbling)

Doctor: That’s nice but you got to come back. So when are you coming back? Doctor: Okay. I mean it’s fine if you want to stay there. PAT Yeah. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: It’s not like the medicine is gonna be delivered tomorrow. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: By the time I work out all this paperwork, it’s a while. Patient: Okay, alright. That’s cool. Doctor: So you duke it out with your wife – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - in terms of whether you go or not, that’s on you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You just know, I have to have you be careful. Patient: I know.

Family Member 2: So he has taken some Ambien once in a while to sleep, is that okay or no? Doctor: We'll we'll check the protocol to make sure there's no future drug interaction, but I think it's fine Family Member 2: Okay, do you want a prescription referral? Do you need a prescription? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Is that okay? I don't have any left. Doctor: We always prefer Restiril, have you ever been? So that's actually probably a better sleeper. Family Member 2: Restiril. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: It’s pretty strong. Doctor: I like that better and less addictive than Ambien. Family Member 1: Oh, okay. Okay, questions. My one daughter is pregnant. Then we watch her her little two year old. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: About three times a week.

Patient: No. Doctor: Holding his own, getting worse, better? Family Member: I think he’s basically holding his own. Family Member 1: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. And I see you still use a cane? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Anything new on your body you want me to take a look at? Bumps, lumps? Patient: Yeah. Since you took, you said that. Right, huh, huh, huh, right there. It feels like a, a scab. But then sometimes it feels like a, a needle. Doctor: But you can pinpoint it to the one place? Patient: Yep. Doctor: That’s a little dry skin there. Okay. Patient: And then you scratch it- Doctor: Anything else to look at? Any swelling or anything?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I bet within the month you’re maybe won’t need those pads anymore. Patient: Because the other thing too is uh I coach my daughters softball team so of course get that grade down, a bucket of ball (FAM Laughs) Doctor: So even a year or two from now it’s not gonna be – you don’t have as much resistance to outflow as you used to have. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But it should be enough that you would be dry almost all the time. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Still if you cough or pick up a heavy weight – Patient: Mm,hmm. Doctor: - still even a few years from now maybe a drop or two might come out. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Hmm, okay. (Pause) Doctor: It means that um there’s not enough prostate cancer cells to be detectable by the blood test.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but that would be another possibility, I think, uh- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: -that we could consider. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, if you’re, uh, again, the easiest thing is going to be to do the hormone therapy straight up. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So, uh, we could potentially do the hormone therapy and then do the vaccine, also. Okay? Patient: Right. Doctor: So, uh. Patient: What did you think about that? Because I know you think differently than I do. Doctor: And so the Xtandi trials we have are Xtandi plus, uh, one of the drugs affect kind of the hormone pathways in different ways. Uh, so there’s some reason why they would work together with Xtandi. Uh, one of them is an immune drug itself. Uh, that immune drug, that, that trial, you get either the Xtandi plus the immune drug or just the Xtandi alone, but it requires biopsy. Uh, the other, the other trial we have is Xtandi plus, uh, a drug that affects we think a signal that the cancers can use as an alternative to the hormone signal. So they kind of switch over. So our idea is to block both signals to see if that would help. That, I think you get both drugs, uh, but, again, it also requires a biopsy. Family Member: Right.

Patient: Well you know I ordered some more yeah. Doctor: Oh you got a refill. Patient: I haven’t been doing better. Doctor: Okay but stay with them because what it does it’s not gonna be immediate, it allows the blood flow to go into the penis. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And take it uh like twice a week. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Uh don’t wait you know for having, having sex with somebody, Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: take it so that uh, it’s like medication you would take on a regular basis… Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Take that so that it keeps the blood flow going.

Family Member: If he thinks he has a hernia, would that show on the CT scan? Would that be appropriate to send to the doctor? Doctor: No, because, yeah, the hernia, you know, when you’re laying down it really has to be pretty bad for it to be seen laying down. It’s usually when you’re standing up or sitting that it comes out. A hernia just means you have a weak area of muscle and then you have your bowel spill out. Typically, it doesn’t bother you unless it gets stuck, you know. Patient: Okay. Family Member: He’s having a lot of pain shooting up. Patient: Just I have a problem with my groin Doctor: Yeah. Patient: because that’s another problem I’m having to get my doctor to maybe get that taken, Doctor: Yeah. Patient: but it don’t hurt walking Doctor: No. Patient: or doing anything so. Doctor: Yeah, so you’ve seen a surgeon specifically for the hernia?

Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: you know it’s not in his head, it’s here and that’s the only part that could go wrong. Family Member: So doctor he hears that it’s okay for him to be on that motorcycle? Doctor: What I’m saying is, for me, I don’t advise it. But if you say medically if there is some reason you can’t be on it, no. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So if he asks me is there a medical reason why I can’t be on it? No. Do I think it’s a good idea? Not really. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But you know I’m not, I’m not the one that can tell you. You have to use common sense. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s not like you’re going up north, you’re going to F__. Patient: Yeah, well Doc I went to C__. Doctor: I got ya, but that was way before you got sick.

Patient: I have great confidence in him as I do with you, but as you know. Doctor: Yep. No. I was picking his brain. Patient: You’ve got to ask twice. You know? Doctor: Every time. Every time. Patient: You know? Doctor: So he says hello and he’s happy you’re doing well. It’s just trying to a – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: get ahead of it. Patient: Um. Doctor: Do you feel any better from the radiation? Patient: My back is much better. Doctor: Okay.
